I'll now produce a draft answer.</think>Below is one way to “unpack” the relationships step‐by‐step. (Note that without all of the context for what the k‑values represent, we must work only with the numbers given.)

──────────────────────────────
1) Comparing k10 and k9

We are told:
  k9 = 467 
  k10 = 514

Since
  514 – 47 = 467,
we immediately see that

  k9 = k10 – 47.

This tells us that the two keys differ by exactly 47. In other words, subtracting 47 from k10 “lands” you at k9. (And note: 47 is a prime number—which might be why it appears in other expressions as well.)

──────────────────────────────
2) Expressing 467 in the form some_key × M + C

One observation given is that we can write:
  467 = k6×9 + 26.
To check this, assume for a moment that k6 has the value 49 (since 9×49 = 441 and 441+26 = 467). In other words,

  k9 = 9 × 49 + 26  with 49 = k6.

Thus one acceptable “linear‐in–a–parameter” representation of 467 is

  467 = (some_key)×(M) + C,
with some_key = k6, M = 9, and C = 26.
Also note that the constant 26 factors as 2 × 13, which may be a hint toward other hidden patterns.

──────────────────────────────
3) The significance of 47

Because k10 – k9 = 514 – 467 = 47 and because 47 is prime, its appearance is nonaccidental. In the “known” formulas the number 47 shows up in different guises (for example it is explicitly present on the left and also appears as part of an expression like “k8×47 + 16”). This reinforces the idea that 47 is a key constant in this system.

──────────────────────────────
4) Why write 467 = k6×9 + 26?

Writing

  467 = 9 × 49 + 26,
shows one way to “break up” 467 into two parts. (Here we have taken k6 = 49 so that 9 × 49 = 441 and then added 26.) In many puzzles or number‐series problems it is suggestive when a prime like 47 shows up as both the difference between keys and as part of another “nice” expression.

──────────────────────────────
5) The simplest formula for k9

There are at least two equally acceptable simple formulas:

• Since we already saw that
  k9 = k10 – 47,
this is very direct. It shows immediately how k9 is obtained from k10 by subtracting the prime 47.

• Alternatively, using the given relation for k10 (namely that k10 = k3×k7 – 18), we have
  k9 = [k3×k7 – 18] – 47 
which rearranges to
  k9 = k3×k7 – 65.

Both of these formulas are “simple” in that they express k9 directly in terms of other keys or known numbers. Which one is simplest may depend on what quantities you wish to highlight. If you want to emphasize the offset between k10 and k9 then

  k9 = k10 – 47

is very clear.

──────────────────────────────
Summary Answer

Yes, k9 can be written as k10 – 47 (since 514 – 47 = 467). In addition one may note that if k6 = 49 then
  k9 = 9 × 49 + 26.
Also, since k10 was given by k3×k7 – 18, subtracting 47 shows that
  k9 = k3×k7 – 65.

Thus one of the simplest formulas is

  k9 = k10 – 47.
